searchDocs.title: Installationâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Add Quid to your wally.toml:  Quid = "6531503070/quid@1.0.0"   tip If you're new to Wally, check out the Wally installation guide.

searchDocs.title: Basic Setupâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Here's how to set up Quid with a simple data structure:  local Quid = require(path.to.quid) local uid = Quid.next()

searchDocs.title: ðŸš€ Featuresâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Version-detectable: The uid can represent the version of item/entity data schemaK-Sortable: The uid can be K-sortable as it is time-basedRandom-Customizable: The random specification can be customized, by providing a configHuman-Friendly: Human-friendly writing and reading, as it is represented as base64url

searchDocs.title: ðŸ§¬ Quid's Data Structureâ€‹
searchDocs.content: Quid IDs are always 26 fixed characters long, encoded in base64url, and contain version, timestamp, and uniqueness information.  Structure: vvvttttttttUUUUUUUUUUUUUUU (26 fixed characters, 156 bits)  flowchart LR A["vvv<br/>Version<br/>3 chars<br/>18 bits"] --> B["tttttttt<br/>Timestamp<br/>8 chars<br/>48 bits"] --> C["UUUUUUUUUUUUUUU<br/>Uniqueness<br/>15 chars<br/>90 bits"]   Section	Characters	Bits	Descriptionvvv	3	18	Version (up to 262,143 versions) tttttttt	8	48	Timestamp (up to ~8,919 years) UUUUUUUUUUUUUUU	15	90	Uniqueness (up to 1.2e27 unique values)

searchDocs.title: versionâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Config.version: number  TIP It's can be used as a number for comparing version and then apply to item / entity schema or data-transformation.

searchDocs.title: fingerprintâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Config.fingerprint: string  TIP It's can be represent as a machine-id, place-id, job-id, etc. for better randomness. But it depends on your entropy factory function too.

searchDocs.title: clockâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Config.clock() â†’Â number-- A unix-timestamp in milliseconds as a integer. A factory function for produce unix-timestamp in milliseconds as a integer. TIP You can overwrite this, and implement your own clock function.

searchDocs.title: entropyâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Config.entropy( version:Â number, timestamp:Â number, fingerprint:Â string, counter:Â number ) â†’Â number-- A random number between [0, 1] A factory function for produce random number between [0, 1] TIP You can overwrite this, and implement your own entropy function.

searchDocs.title: nextâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Quid.next( version:Â number?, timestamp:Â number? ) â†’Â string-- quid Generate a new quid with global config state

searchDocs.title: parseâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Quid.parse(quid:Â string) â†’Â ( number,-- Version number,-- Timestamp number-- Uniqueness ) Parse a quid string into its components

searchDocs.title: isâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Quid.is(x:Â anyÂ |Â string?) â†’Â boolean Check if x is a valid quid

searchDocs.title: updateâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Quid.update( quid:Â string, target_version:Â number?-- If nil: increment +1 (Can be decrease or increase) ) â†’Â ( string,-- Updated quid number?-- Target version (If nil: not updated) ) Update a version of quid

searchDocs.title: Errors
searchDocs.content: Type	Description"Invalid quid"	quid is a base64url string and must be 28 characters

searchDocs.title: newâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Quid.new(config:Â Config?) â†’Â Quid<Config>-- Quid object Create a new quid object with custom config state

searchDocs.title: Nextâ€‹
searchDocs.content: </> Quid:Next( version:Â number?, timestamp:Â number? ) â†’Â string-- quid Generate a new quid with local config state
